Originally named '''the Cranberry Saw Us''', the band were formed in 1989 by lead singer Niall Quinn, guitarist [[Noel Hogan]], bassist Mike Hogan and drummer Fergal Lawler. Quinn was replaced as lead singer by [[Dolores O'Riordan]] in 1990 and they changed their name to the Cranberries. The band classified themselves as an [[alternative rock]] group, but incorporated aspects of [[indie rock]], [[jangle pop]], [[folk rock]], [[post-punk]] and [[pop rock]] into their sound. The Cranberries rose to international fame in the 1990s with their debut album, ''[[Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?]]'', which became a commercial success. Some of the band's hit singles include "[[Dreams (The Cranberries song)|Dreams]]" (1992), "[[Linger (The Cranberries song)|Linger]]" (1993), "[[Zombie (The Cranberries song)|Zombie]]" (1994), "[[Salvation (The Cranberries song)|Salvation]]" (1996), and "[[When You're Gone (The Cranberries song)|When You're Gone]]" (1997). April 2020}} The Cranberries rank as one of the best-selling alternative acts of the 1990s, having sold nearly 50 million albums worldwide as of 2019. They have received an [[MTV Europe Music Award]], a [[World Music Award]], an International Group nomination at the [[Brit Awards]], a [[Juno Award|Juno]] nomination, a Juno Award win, an Ivor Novello Award for International Achievement and a [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI Award]] with a Special Citation of Achievement. ''In the End'' earned them a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nomination for Best Rock Album. With the video for their song "Zombie", the Cranberries became the first Irish band to reach one billion views on [[List of most-viewed YouTube videos#Billion-View Club|YouTube]]. ==History== ===Formation and early years (1989–1992)=== Brothers [[Noel Hogan]] and Mike Hogan, descendants of the nineteenth-century Irish poet [[Michael Hogan (poet)|Michael Hogan]], met Fergal Lawler in the mid-1980s.{{sfn|Rees|Crampton|1999|p=248}}{{cite magazine|url=https://www.moderndrummer.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/md191cs.pdf|title=Fergal Lawler|website=Modern Drummer |year= 1995|publisher=David Frangioni|location=USA|issn=0194-4533|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200408192338/https://www.moderndrummer.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/md191cs.pdf|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} The young kids who grew up together in [[Limerick]], Ireland, also shared their love of 1980s English/[[indie music]] and were "galvanised by punk's [[DIY ethic]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.udiscovermusic.com/stories/noel-hogan-cranberries-everybody-else-interview/|title=It Was The Perfect Time And Place|last=Peacock|first=Tim|website=uDiscoverMusic|date=19 October 2018|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-123232/https://www.udiscovermusic.com/stories/noel-hogan-cranberries-everybody-else-interview/|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}}{{cite web|url=https://crypticrock.com/interview-noel-hogan-of-the-cranberries/|title=Interview – Noel Hogan|website=Cryptic Rock|date=27 December 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-123536/https://crypticrock.com/interview-noel-hogan-of-the-cranberries/|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} Lawler received his first drum kit as a Christmas present when he was about seventeen; two months later, Mike Hogan received his first bass and his brother his first guitar. Niall Quinn, who also lived in the region, played with his own group called [[Hitchers (band)|Hitchers]] and occasionally shared his experiences with the trio. Thereafter, they moved towards the idea of a four-piece ensemble and Quinn decided to stay on with the band. In mid-1989, brothers Mike (16) and Noel (18) Hogan formed the Cranberry Saw Us with Lawler (18), and singer Quinn.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=21}}{{sfn|Bianco|Knight|1998|p=37}} The Cranberry Saw Us' initial release was the demo EP ''[[Anything (The Cranberry Saw Us demo)|Anything]]'' in January 1990. Shortly afterwards, Quinn left the band to return to his previous group Hitchers, although they remained on good terms.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=22}}{{cite news|last=Peacock|first=Tim|date=30 August 2018|title=25th anniversary edition of 'Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?'|url=https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/cranberries-25th-everybody-else/|work=uDiscoverMusic|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-100729/https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/cranberries-25th-everybody-else/|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=5 April 2021}} Despite this unexpected break-up, the three musicians transitioned to an instrumental group for several months, continuing to improve on ideas and song structures of instrumental pieces. Lawler and the two Hogan brothers then placed an advertisement for a female singer.The Cranberries Loud & Clear World Tour Programme, "A Timeline of the Cranberries 1989–'99", pp. 8–10. Subsequently, Quinn introduced the trio to a friend of his girlfriend's sister, mentioning that she was a singer-songwriter looking for a group who would compose original music. On a Sunday afternoon in mid-1990, 18-year-old [[Dolores O'Riordan]] cycled to the audition at Xeric Studios dressed in a tracksuit and with a broken [[Casio keyboard]] under her arm.{{cite web|url=https://www.hotpress.com/culture/ode-to-dolores-the-full-hot-press-cover-story-on-dolores-oriordan-21734931|title=Ode To Dolores|last=Clark|first=Stuart|website=HotPress|date=7 February 2018|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-124444/https://www.hotpress.com/culture/ode-to-dolores-the-full-hot-press-cover-story-on-dolores-oriordan-21734931|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}}{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/the-cranberries-final-album-interview-790271/|title=The Making of the Cranberries' Haunted Farewell|last=Browne|first=David|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=7 February 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.02.12-182354/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/the-cranberries-final-album-interview-790271/|archive-date=12 February 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} O'Riordan said of the first encounter "I really liked what I heard; I thought they were very nice and tight. It was a lovely potential band but they needed a singer – and direction". Noel Hogan gave her a rough cassette demo incorporating chord sequences of indie-[[Jangle|jangly]] guitar sounds, then O'Riordan took home Hogan's tape and began writing lyrics and overlaying melodies which would underpin the group's future material. Within a week, she returned to the musicians with whom she sang along a rough version of "Linger". Mike Hogan later described it as "we were immediately blown away, her voice was something special". Noel Hogan elaborated, "she was so small and quiet... then she opened her mouth and this amazing voice, this huge voice came out for the size of her";{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2019/04/23/713529217/the-cranberries-final-album-celebrates-the-new-beginning-dolores-o-riordan-wante?t=1575744084687&t=1586214906649|title=Music Interviews|last=Martin|first=Rachel|publisher=NPR|date=23 April 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-144038/https://www.npr.org/2019/04/23/713529217/the-cranberries-final-album-celebrates-the-new-beginning-dolores-o-riordan-wante?t=1575744084687&t=1586214906649|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} and then acknowledged: "how come she's not already in a band? [...] that day changed our lives". A musical relationship rapidly developed between O'Riordan and Noel Hogan, who had enough songs to design a demo.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/dolores-oriordan-and-the-cranberries-strange-fruit-72247/|title=The improbable rise of Ireland's biggest musical export since U2|last=Foege|first=Alec|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=23 March 1995|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-144357/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/dolores-oriordan-and-the-cranberries-strange-fruit-72247/|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} The fledgling band recorded a four-track demo EP called ''[[Water Circle]]'', released in cassette format by local record label Xeric Records.{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/thepitch/the-cranberries-were-the-ultimate-teen-soundtrack-band/|title=The Cranberries|last=Berman|first=Judy|website=Pitchfork|date=17 January 2018|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118012204/https://pitchfork.com/thepitch/the-cranberries-were-the-ultimate-teen-soundtrack-band/|archive-date=18 January 2018|access-date=8 April 2020}}{{cite web|url=https://musicbrainz.org/release/ce9edf12-b5c7-4acd-b008-c5760742342f|title=Water Circle release by The Cranberry Saw Us|website=MusicBrainz|date=22 September 2011|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-145659/https://musicbrainz.org/release/ce9edf12-b5c7-4acd-b008-c5760742342f|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} In July 1990, the group performed their first gig with O'Riordan at a hotel basement called Ruby's Club, Cruises Hotel, Limerick, performing six original songs to an audience of 60 people including three other local groups.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=25}} The Cranberry Saw Us moved to Xeric Recording studio and recorded ''[[Nothing Left at All]]'',{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=24}} their first commercial three-track EP released on tape in 300 copies by Xeric Records, which sold out in local record shops in Limerick within a few days.{{cite web|url=https://musicbrainz.org/release/870e3053-2561-4961-b487-be542a0817c1|title=Nothing Left at All release by The Cranberry Saw Us|website=MusicBrainz|date=22 September 2011|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-145915/https://musicbrainz.org/release/870e3053-2561-4961-b487-be542a0817c1|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}}{{cite web|url=https://www.whytes.ie/art/the-cranberries-nothing-left-at-all-1990-cassette-tape/144410/?SearchString=&LotNumSearch=&GuidePrice=&OrderBy=LH&ArtistID=&ArrangeBy=list&NumPerPage=15&offset=149|title=Nothing Left At All 1990 cassette tape|website=Whyte's|date=30 May 2014|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-150233/https://www.whytes.ie/art/the-cranberries-nothing-left-at-all-1990-cassette-tape/144410/?SearchString=&LotNumSearch=&GuidePrice=&OrderBy=LH&ArtistID=&ArrangeBy=list&NumPerPage=15&offset=149|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} The owner of Xeric Studios, Pearse Gilmore, became their manager and provided the group with studio time to complete a demo tape, which he produced. It featured early versions of "[[Linger (The Cranberries song)|Linger]]" and "[[Dreams (The Cranberries song)|Dreams]]", which were sent directly to record companies in London by Noel Hogan, determined to leave the [[Underground culture|underground circuit]] of small Irish clubs and pubs.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=26}} [[Rough Trade Records|Rough Trade]] label founder [[Geoff Travis]] immediately gave his approval, and although the Cranberries did not sign on to his label the demo continued to earn the attention of both the UK [[History of British newspapers|press]] and record industry and sparked a bidding war between major British record labels.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=26}} On 18 April 1991, the group played a decisive show in their hometown at Jetland Center as part of the [[University of Limerick]]'s [[RAG Week]] to 1,400 students. In attendance was record producer [[Denny Cordell]], who was then [[Artists and repertoire|A&R]] for [[Island Records]], and thirty-two other A&R men who flew from London. Shortly thereafter, the band changed their name to "The Cranberries".{{cite web|url=https://fanningsessions.wordpress.com/2011/02/23/cork-rocks-1991/|title=Cork Rock (1991)|last=Fanning|first=Dave|website=The Fanning Sessions|date=23 February 2011|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2012.07.07-221006/http://fanningsessions.wordpress.com/2011/02/23/cork-rocks-1991/|archive-date=7 July 2012|access-date=8 April 2020}} ''Nothing Left at All'' began to circulate in the UK with the support of John Best PR agency.{{sfn|Rees|Crampton|1999|p=248}} Then, they performed their first UK tour opening for the British band [[Moose (band)|Moose]] over the course of three weeks.{{sfn|Rees|Crampton|1999|p=248}} The Cranberries received more letters expressing interest from [[Virgin Records|Virgin]], [[EMI Records|EMI]], [[Imago Records|Imago]], [[CBS Records International|CBS]], and [[Warner Records|Warner]], which led the Hogan brothers to quit their jobs. Eventually the group signed a six-album deal with [[Island Records]] who won the battle through Denny Cordell.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|pp=25–26}}{{sfn|Rees|Crampton|1999|p=248}} In mid-1991, the Cranberries headed back into the studio with Gilmore as their producer to "hastily" record their first EP ''[[Uncertain (EP)|Uncertain]]'' and created a music video for the title track, which was not released. Gilmore, in an incoherent gesture, made various alterations to the album's rough cuts.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=27}} 5,000 total copies of ''Uncertain'' were printed and released in October 1991 by Island Records under the Xeric name.{{cite web|url=https://musicbrainz.org/release/3abd4cd5-08af-49bf-bb17-ecd2918847fc|title=Uncertain release by The Cranberries|website=MusicBrainz|date=12 February 2015|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-152914/https://musicbrainz.org/release/3abd4cd5-08af-49bf-bb17-ecd2918847fc|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} The EP received poor reviews in the press and led to tension between the group and Gilmore.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=27}} By this time, Gilmore began restricting information to the Cranberries and made separate arrangements with Island's U.S branch. In October 1991 the Cranberries performed at [[Camden Underworld|Underworld]] in London during a UK and Ireland tour. Adding to this period of doubt, touring conditions and money were lacking with maximum earnings of $25 a day.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|pp=25–26}} On 9 December 1991, the Cranberries was supposed to support [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] in [[Belfast]]'s Conor Hall, but Nirvana canceled their tour at the last moment as well as the [[List of Nirvana concerts|five remaining shows]] due to [[Kurt Cobain]]'s ill health.{{cite web|url=https://www.livenirvana.com/concerts/cancelled.php|title=Live Nirvana Concert Chronology – Cancelled Shows|website=LiveNIRVANA.com|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-153227/https://www.livenirvana.com/concerts/cancelled.php|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-46509946|title=King's Hall concerts from The Beatles to Nirvana|last=Kearney|first=Joe|publisher=BBC News|date=12 January 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.08-153648/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-46509946|archive-date=8 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} After a difficult recording session, intended for their [[Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?|first album]] on Island Records in January 1992, the band scrapped their work and fired Gilmore.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=27}} Noel Hogan stated "we didn't have a problem with each other, we had a problem with this guy". During that period the Cranberries toured Ireland and the UK as the opening act for TOP, gaining more attention from the British press.{{sfn|Reisfeld|1996|p=28}} Subsequently, they hired [[Geoff Travis]] as their new manager. The Cranberries headed back into the studio in [[Dublin]] in March 1992 to restart working on their first LP with [[Stephen Street]], who had previously worked with [[the Smiths]].{{sfn|Bianco|Knight|1998|p=38}} The Cranberries began a UK and Ireland headlining tour during the last four months of 1992 to promote the subsequent release of ''[[Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?]]''.{{sfn|Rees|Crampton|1999|p=248}} In October 1992, "[[Dreams (The Cranberries song)|Dreams]]" was released in the UK, becoming ''[[Melody Maker]]''{{'}}s single of the week.{{sfn|Bianco|Knight|1998|p=40}} In November 1992, they performed at the emblematic [[Royal Albert Hall]] supporting [[Mercury Rev]] and [[the House of Love]].{{sfn|Rees|Crampton|1999|p=248}} Between 1991 and 1993, the band also recorded several [[The Cranberries radio and television sessions|studio and live sessions]] intended for Irish and British radio and television shows, including [[2fm]]'s ''[[The Dave Fanning Show]]'' in Dublin and [[BBC Radio 1]]'s ''[[John Peel]] Show''.{{cite web|url=https://pastdaily.com/2018/01/15/dolores-oriordan-1991-past-daily-memorial-edition/|title=Dolores O'Riordan – The Cranberries In Session – 1991|last=Skene|first=Gordon|website=Past Daily|date=15 January 2018|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.05-161639/https://pastdaily.com/2018/01/15/dolores-oriordan-1991-past-daily-memorial-edition/|archive-date=5 April 2020|access-date=8 April 2020}} ===Breakthrough and mainstream success (1993–1995)=== {{See also|Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?|No Need to Argue}}[[File:The Cranberries at Roxy Bar 1995.jpg|alt=O'Riordan onstage with a large acoustic guitar|thumb|150px|left|upright|O'Riordan singing onstage at the height of their fame, 1995]] The second single of their debut album, "Linger", was first released in the UK in February 1993, peaking at No. 74. Their first full-length album ''[[Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?]]'' was released 1 March 1993. Although ''Bury the Hatchet'' was a major seller, the album marked a sales decrease compared to their previous releases.{{cite magazine|last=Sexton|first=Paul|date=27 October 2001|title=Cranberries 'Wake' To New Beginning|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA14|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|volume=113|issue=43|page=14|issn=0006-2510|access-date=18 April 2021|archive-date=18 April 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210418162514/https://books.google.com/books?id=kBEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA14|url-status=live}} {{Listen|filename=The Cranberries - Wake Up And Smell The Coffee.ogg|title="Wake Up and Smell the Coffee"|description=Sample of "Wake Up and Smell the Coffee" by the Cranberries, from ''[[Wake Up and Smell the Coffee]]'' (2001)}} In late 2001, the Cranberries had sold more than 33 million albums worldwide. The album peaked at No. 46 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and No. 2 on the Spanish, Italian and French album charts. It went to No. 8 on the ''Billboard'' [[Canadian Albums Chart]] and reached No. 61 in the UK.{{cite web|url=https://pure-music.co.uk/wake-up-and-smell-the-coffee-album-cover/|title="Wake Up And Smell The Coffee" is the fifth studio album released by Irish alternative rock band The Cranberries|website=www.pure-music.co.uk|date=5 April 2019|access-date=10 November 2019|archive-date=10 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191110151540/https://pure-music.co.uk/wake-up-and-smell-the-coffee-album-cover/|url-status=live}} The first single released from the album was "[[Analyse (Cranberries song)|Analyse]]", which charted in the US Adult Top 40 at a peak of 26. In September, a greatest hits album was released entitled ''[[Stars: The Best of 1992–2002]]'', which was released alongside an [[Stars: The Best of 1992–2002#DVD|eponymous DVD]] of music videos. The album peaked in the UK at No. 20. The song "[[Stars (The Cranberries song)|Stars]]" was released as a single from that album. They started a European tour in mid-October 2002 and ended in December. In January 2003, following advice from their legal advisors, the Cranberries parted ways with record label [[MCA Records|MCA]], due to the band's dissatisfaction with the promotion of ''Wake Up and Smell the Coffee''.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/72598/cranberries-terminate-mca-contract|title=Cranberries Terminate MCA Contract|magazine=Billboard|date=22 January 2003|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.13-111403/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/72598/cranberries-terminate-mca-contract|archive-date=13 April 2020|access-date=13 April 2020}}{{cite web|url=https://www.hotpress.com/music/cranberries-split-from-mca-2634515|title=Cranberries split from MCA|website=Hot Press|date=21 January 2003|url-status=live|archive-url=https://archive.today/2020.04.13-111615/https://www.hotpress.com/music/cranberries-split-from-mca-2634515|archive-date=13 April 2020|access-date=13 April 2020}} [[Noel Hogan]] observed "with little effort from our label, we have been pleased to see top-10 sales in many countries". The Cranberries signed in 1991 with [[Island Records]] America, which was transferred to [[MCA Records|MCA]] in 2000 following a contract renegotiation.
